(ACRSLF) model. The proposed ACRSLF adopts the two-fold ideas: 1) self-tuning
cubic regularization that dynamically mitigates non-convex optimization
instabilities; 2) multi-Hessian-vector product evaluation during conjugate
gradient iterations for precise second-order information assimilation.
Comprehensive experiments on two industrial HDI datasets demonstrate that the
ACRSLF converges faster and achieves higher representation accuracy than the
advancing optimizer-based LFA models.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the Adaptive Cubic Regularized Second-Order Latent Factor (ACRSLF) model for handling high-dimensional and incomplete data.
AI.motivation: Address modeling challenges in high-dimensional and incomplete data, especially due to optimization complexities in second-order latent factor models.
AI.method: Proposes the ACRSLF model using self-tuning cubic regularization and multi-Hessian-vector evaluations for improved optimization and representation.
AI.result: Experiments on industrial HDI datasets show faster convergence and higher accuracy than existing optimizer-based LFA models.
AI.conclusion: The ACRSLF model effectively overcomes challenges in modeling HDI data, providing enhanced performance and optimization stability.

title: Transformer with Koopman-Enhanced Graph Convolutional Network for Spatiotemporal Dynamics Forecasting
summary:
Spatiotemporal dynamics forecasting is inherently challenging, particularly
in systems defined over irregular geometric domains, due to the need to jointly
capture complex spatial correlations and nonlinear temporal dynamics. To tackle
these challenges, we propose TK-GCN, a two-stage framework that integrates
geometry-aware spatial encoding with long-range temporal modeling. In the first
stage, a Koopman-enhanced Graph Convolutional Network (K-GCN) is developed to
embed the high-dimensional dynamics distributed on spatially irregular domains
into a latent space where the evolution of system states is approximately
linear. By leveraging Koopman operator theory, this stage enhances the temporal
consistency during the latent learning. In the second stage, a Transformer
module is employed to model the temporal progression within the Koopman-encoded
latent space. Through the self-attention mechanism, the Transformer captures
long-range temporal dependencies, enabling accurate forecasting over extended
horizons. We evaluate TK-GCN in spatiotemporal cardiac dynamics forecasting and
benchmark its performance against several state-of-the-art baselines.
Experimental results and ablation studies show that TK-GCN consistently
delivers superior predictive accuracy across a range of forecast horizons,
demonstrating its capability to effectively model complex spatial structures
and nonlinear temporal dynamics.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes TK-GCN, a two-stage framework that combines spatial and temporal modeling techniques to improve spatiotemporal dynamics forecasting on irregular geometric domains.
AI.motivation: Spatiotemporal dynamics forecasting is challenging due to the complexities in capturing spatial correlations and nonlinear temporal dynamics, especially on irregular geographic domains.
AI.method: The proposed TK-GCN framework includes two stages: 1) a Koopman-enhanced Graph Convolutional Network (K-GCN) for spatial encoding and linearizing the temporal dynamics in a latent space, and 2) a Transformer module for long-range temporal modeling via self-attention on the latent space.
AI.result: Experimental evaluations, including ablation studies, show that TK-GCN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in spatiotemporal cardiac dynamics forecasting over various forecast horizons.
AI.conclusion: TK-GCN effectively models complex spatial structures and nonlinear temporal dynamics, making it a powerful tool for challenging spatiotemporal forecasting tasks.

title: AI-driven Web Application for Early Detection of Sudden Death Syndrome (SDS) in Soybean Leaves Using Hyperspectral Images and Genetic Algorithm
summary:
Sudden Death Syndrome (SDS), caused by Fusarium virguliforme, poses a
significant threat to soybean production. This study presents an AI-driven web
application for early detection of SDS on soybean leaves using hyperspectral
imaging, enabling diagnosis prior to visible symptom onset. Leaf samples from
healthy and inoculated plants were scanned using a portable hyperspectral
imaging system (398-1011 nm), and a Genetic Algorithm was employed to select
five informative wavelengths (505.4, 563.7, 712.2, 812.9, and 908.4 nm)
critical for discriminating infection status. These selected bands were fed
into a lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to extract
spatial-spectral features, which were subsequently classified using ten
classical machine learning models. Ensemble classifiers (Random Forest,
AdaBoost), Linear SVM, and Neural Net achieved the highest accuracy (>98%) and
minimal error across all folds, as confirmed by confusion matrices and
cross-validation metrics. Poor performance by Gaussian Process and QDA
highlighted their unsuitability for this dataset. The trained models were
deployed within a web application that enables users to upload hyperspectral
leaf images, visualize spectral profiles, and receive real-time classification
results. This system supports rapid and accessible plant disease diagnostics,
contributing to precision agriculture practices. Future work will expand the
training dataset to encompass diverse genotypes, field conditions, and disease
stages, and will extend the system for multiclass disease classification and
broader crop applicability.

AI.tldr: An AI-driven web application was developed to detect Sudden Death Syndrome (SDS) in soybean leaves using hyperspectral imaging, achieving over 98% accuracy via machine learning classifiers.
AI.motivation: The study aims to address the critical challenge of early detection of SDS in soybean production, preventing significant economic losses by diagnosing the disease before visible symptoms appear.
AI.method: The researchers used hyperspectral imaging to collect spectral data from soybean leaves, employed a Genetic Algorithm to select five key wavelengths, and utilized a lightweight CNN for feature extraction. Ten classical machine learning models were tested, with the best-performing ones integrated into a web application.
AI.result: Ensemble classifiers (Random Forest, AdaBoost), Linear SVM, and Neural Net achieved the highest accuracy of over 98%, enabling reliable disease diagnosis. The models were implemented in a web app for real-time use.
AI.conclusion: The study successfully developed a highly accurate and accessible AI-driven system for early SDS detection, contributing to precision agriculture. Future efforts will focus on dataset expansion and adaptation for other crops and diseases.

title: K-Function: Joint Pronunciation Transcription and Feedback for Evaluating Kids Language Function
summary:
Early evaluation of children's language is frustrated by the high pitch, long
phones, and sparse data that derail automatic speech recognisers. We introduce
K-Function, a unified framework that combines accurate sub-word transcription,
objective scoring, and actionable feedback. Its core, Kids-WFST, merges a
Wav2Vec2 phoneme encoder with a phoneme-similarity Dysfluent-WFST to capture
child-specific errors while remaining fully interpretable. Kids-WFST attains
1.39% phoneme error on MyST and 8.61% on Multitudes--absolute gains of 10.47
and 7.06 points over a greedy-search decoder. These high-fidelity transcripts
power an LLM that grades verbal skills, milestones, reading, and comprehension,
aligning with human proctors and supplying tongue-and-lip visualizations plus
targeted advice. The results show that precise phoneme recognition cements a
complete diagnostic-feedback loop, paving the way for scalable, clinician-ready
language assessment.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces K-Function, a framework for early and accurate evaluation of children's language abilities, using Kids-WFST to achieve precise phoneme recognition and provide actionable feedback.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address challenges in automatically assessing children's language skills, including high pitch, long phones, and sparse data, which hinder conventional speech recognizers.
AI.method: The method combines a Wav2Vec2-based phoneme encoder with a phoneme-similarity Dysfluent-WFST to capture child-specific speech errors, enabling interpretable phoneme transcription and further analysis using an LLM for grading and feedback.
AI.result: Kids-WFST achieves significant performance improvements, with a phoneme error rate of 1.39% on MyST and 8.61% on Multitudes, outperforming greedy-search decoders by 10.47 and 7.06 percentage points, respectively.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates that precise phoneme recognition enables a complete diagnostic-feedback loop for scalable and clinician-ready language assessment of children.

title: "Hi AirStar, Guide Me to the Badminton Court."
summary:
Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, operating in environments with relatively few
obstacles, offer high maneuverability and full three-dimensional mobility. This
allows them to rapidly approach objects and perform a wide range of tasks often
challenging for ground robots, making them ideal for exploration, inspection,
aerial imaging, and everyday assistance. In this paper, we introduce AirStar, a
UAV-centric embodied platform that turns a UAV into an intelligent aerial
assistant: a large language model acts as the cognitive core for environmental
understanding, contextual reasoning, and task planning. AirStar accepts natural
interaction through voice commands and gestures, removing the need for a remote
controller and significantly broadening its user base. It combines geospatial
knowledge-driven long-distance navigation with contextual reasoning for
fine-grained short-range control, resulting in an efficient and accurate
vision-and-language navigation (VLN) capability.Furthermore, the system also
offers built-in capabilities such as cross-modal question answering,
intelligent filming, and target tracking. With a highly extensible framework,
it supports seamless integration of new functionalities, paving the way toward
a general-purpose, instruction-driven intelligent UAV agent. The supplementary
PPT is available at
\href{https://buaa-colalab.github.io/airstar.github.io}{https://buaa-colalab.github.io/airstar.github.io}.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces AirStar, a UAV equipped with a large language model enabling natural interaction, geospatial navigation, and cross-modal capabilities, aimed at becoming a versatile aerial assistant.
AI.motivation: To enhance UAV usability beyond basic operations by integrating intelligent interaction and task-planning capabilities.
AI.method: AirStar employs a large language model for cognitive processing, accepting voice and gesture-based commands. It integrates geospatial navigation for long-range tasks with contextual reasoning for precise short-range control.
AI.result: The system achieves efficient vision-and-language navigation and supports functions like cross-modal Q&A, intelligent filming, and extensible task integration.
AI.conclusion: AirStar stands as a promising platform for general-purpose instruction-driven UAVs, broadening user accessibility while supporting varied tasks in dynamic environments.

title: Uncovering Systemic and Environment Errors in Autonomous Systems Using Differential Testing
summary:
When an autonomous agent behaves undesirably, including failure to complete a
task, it can be difficult to determine whether the behavior is due to a
systemic agent error, such as flaws in the model or policy, or an environment
error, where a task is inherently infeasible under a given environment
configuration, even for an ideal agent. As agents and their environments grow
more complex, identifying the error source becomes increasingly difficult but
critical for reliable deployment. We introduce AIProbe, a novel black-box
testing technique that applies differential testing to attribute undesirable
agent behaviors either to agent deficiencies, such as modeling or training
flaws, or due to environmental infeasibility. AIProbe first generates diverse
environmental configurations and tasks for testing the agent, by modifying
configurable parameters using Latin Hypercube sampling. It then solves each
generated task using a search-based planner, independent of the agent. By
comparing the agent's performance to the planner's solution, AIProbe identifies
whether failures are due to errors in the agent's model or policy, or due to
unsolvable task conditions. Our evaluation across multiple domains shows that
AIProbe significantly outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in detecting both
total and unique errors, thereby contributing to a reliable deployment of
autonomous agents.

AI.tldr: AIProbe is a testing method for determining if failures in autonomous agents arise from the agent itself or from the environment's infeasibility. It uses a differential testing approach involving environmental configurations and a search-based planner.
AI.motivation: Autonomous agents often fail due to either flaws in their model/policies or the infeasibility of tasks in their environment. Distinguishing these failure sources, especially in complex systems, is crucial for deployment reliability.
AI.method: AIProbe uses Latin Hypercube sampling to create varied environmental configurations and then employs a search-based planner to solve tasks independently from the agent. It compares the agent’s results to identify the error source.
AI.result: Experiments with AIProbe demonstrated superior performance over existing methods in detecting both total and unique errors across diverse domains.
AI.conclusion: AIProbe facilitates reliable deployment of autonomous agents by accurately diagnosing failure causes and outperforming state-of-the-art testing techniques.

title: Optimas: Optimizing Compound AI Systems with Globally Aligned Local Rewards
summary:
Compound AI systems integrating multiple components, such as Large Language
Models, specialized tools, and traditional machine learning models, are
increasingly deployed to solve complex real-world tasks. However, optimizing
compound systems remains challenging due to their non-differentiable structures
and diverse configuration types across components, including prompts,
hyperparameters, and model parameters. To address this challenge, we propose
Optimas, a unified framework for effective optimization of compound systems.
The core idea of Optimas is to maintain one Local Reward Function (LRF) per
component, each satisfying a local-global alignment property, i.e., each
component's local reward correlates with the global system performance. In each
iteration, Optimas efficiently adapts the LRFs to maintain this property while
simultaneously maximizing each component's local reward. This approach enables
independent updates of heterogeneous configurations using the designated
optimization method, while ensuring that local improvements consistently lead
to performance gains. We present extensive evaluations across five real-world
compound systems to demonstrate that Optimas outperforms strong baselines by an
average improvement of 11.92%, offering a general and effective approach for
improving compound systems. Our website is at https://optimas.stanford.edu.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Optimas, a framework to optimize compound AI systems, demonstrating significant performance improvements.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to tackle the challenge of optimizing complex AI systems integrating multiple components with diverse configuration types.
AI.method: Optimas utilizes Local Reward Functions (LRFs) for each component to ensure local-global alignment, allowing independent updates while maintaining global performance.
AI.result: Optimas achieves an average performance improvement of 11.92% across five real-world compound systems compared to strong baselines.
AI.conclusion: Optimas offers a general, effective framework for improving compound AI systems, enabling better real-world application optimization.

title: Unraveling the Black-box Magic: An Analysis of Neural Networks' Dynamic Local Extrema
summary:
We point out that neural networks are not black boxes, and their
generalization stems from the ability to dynamically map a dataset to the local
extrema of the model function. We further prove that the number of local
extrema in a neural network is positively correlated with the number of its
parameters, and on this basis, we give a new algorithm that is different from
the back-propagation algorithm, which we call the extremum-increment algorithm.
Some difficult situations, such as gradient vanishing and overfitting, can be
reasonably explained and dealt with in this framework.

AI.tldr: Neural networks generalize by dynamically mapping datasets to local extrema of their function, and a new algorithm addressing limitations of back-propagation is proposed.
AI.motivation: Addressing the common perception of neural networks as black boxes and introducing a framework that explains generalization and resolves challenges like gradient vanishing and overfitting.
AI.method: Proved correlation between the number of local extrema and neural network parameters, and proposed the extremum-increment algorithm to tackle identified issues.
AI.result: The extremum-increment algorithm provides a theoretical basis for managing gradient vanishing and overfitting while explaining neural network generalization.
AI.conclusion: Neural networks are not black boxes; their generalization comes from mapping datasets to local extrema, and the findings contribute to better understanding and tackling challenges using the new algorithm.

title: Development of an Improved Capsule-Yolo Network for Automatic Tomato Plant Disease Early Detection and Diagnosis
summary:
Like many countries, Nigeria is naturally endowed with fertile agricultural
soil that supports large-scale tomato production. However, the prevalence of
disease causing pathogens poses a significant threat to tomato health, often
leading to reduced yields and, in severe cases, the extinction of certain
species. These diseases jeopardise both the quality and quantity of tomato
harvests, contributing to food insecurity. Fortunately, tomato diseases can
often be visually identified through distinct forms, appearances, or textures,
typically first visible on leaves and fruits. This study presents an enhanced
Capsule-YOLO network architecture designed to automatically segment overlapping
and occluded tomato leaf images from complex backgrounds using the YOLO
framework. It identifies disease symptoms with impressive performance metrics:
99.31% accuracy, 98.78% recall, and 99.09% precision, and a 98.93% F1-score
representing improvements of 2.91%, 1.84%, 5.64%, and 4.12% over existing
state-of-the-art methods. Additionally, a user-friendly interface was developed
to allow farmers and users to upload images of affected tomato plants and
detect early disease symptoms. The system also provides recommendations for
appropriate diagnosis and treatment. The effectiveness of this approach
promises significant benefits for the agricultural sector by enhancing crop
yields and strengthening food security.

AI.tldr: This study enhances tomato crop disease identification using an improved Capsule-YOLO network, achieving highly accurate results and a user-friendly interface for farmers.
AI.motivation: The study addresses the challenge of tomato diseases caused by pathogens, which threaten yields, species survival, and food security in Nigeria.
AI.method: An enhanced Capsule-YOLO network was developed to automatically segment overlapping and occluded tomato leaf images, achieving high performance in detecting disease symptoms.
AI.result: The proposed network achieved 99.31% accuracy, 98.78% recall, 99.09% precision, and a 98.93% F1-score, surpassing existing methods by up to 5.64%.
AI.conclusion: This system holds promise for increasing agricultural productivity and food security through timely disease identification and response.

title: Counterfactual Tuning for Temporal Sensitivity Enhancement in Large Language Model-based Recommendation
summary:
Recent advances have applied large language models (LLMs) to sequential
recommendation, leveraging their pre-training knowledge and reasoning
capabilities to provide more personalized user experiences. However, existing
LLM-based methods fail to sufficiently leverage the rich temporal information
inherent in users' historical interaction sequences, stemming from fundamental
architectural constraints: LLMs process information through self-attention
mechanisms that lack inherent sequence ordering and rely on position embeddings
designed primarily for natural language rather than user interaction sequences.
This limitation significantly impairs their ability to capture the evolution of
user preferences over time and predict future interests accurately.
  To address this critical gap, we propose Counterfactual Enhanced Temporal
Framework for LLM-Based Recommendation (CETRec). CETRec is grounded in causal
inference principles, which allow it to isolate and measure the specific impact
of temporal information on recommendation outcomes. By conceptualizing temporal
order as an independent causal factor distinct from item content, we can
quantify its unique contribution through counterfactual reasoning--comparing
what recommendations would be made with and without temporal information while
keeping all other factors constant. This causal framing enables CETRec to
design a novel counterfactual tuning objective that directly optimizes the
model's temporal sensitivity, teaching LLMs to recognize both absolute
timestamps and relative ordering patterns in user histories. Combined with our
counterfactual tuning task derived from causal analysis, CETRec effectively
enhances LLMs' awareness of both absolute order (how recently items were
interacted with) and relative order (the sequential relationships between
items).

AI.tldr: Existing large language models (LLMs) struggle to utilize temporal information in sequential recommendation systems due to architectural limitations. CETRec, a counterfactual-based framework, enhances LLMs' temporal sensitivity for better performance.
AI.motivation: LLMs fail to sufficiently capture temporal information in user interaction histories due to self-attention mechanisms that are not designed for sequence ordering.
AI.method: CETRec applies causal inference principles and counterfactual reasoning to isolate temporal contributions, utilizing a novel tuning objective that teaches LLMs to recognize absolute timestamps and relative ordering in data.
AI.result: CETRec enhances LLMs' sensitivity to chronological order and sequential relationships in user histories, improving their ability to understand evolving preferences.
AI.conclusion: By addressing architectural limitations with counterfactual tuning, CETRec significantly improves LLM-based recommendation systems in capturing temporal dynamics and predicting user interests more accurately.

title: Free-Space Optical Communication-Driven NMPC Framework for Multi-Rotor Aerial Vehicles in Structured Inspection Scenarios
comment:
Accepted for presentation to the 2025 IEEE International Conference
  on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC), Vienna, Austria
summary:
This paper introduces a Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC) framework
for communication-aware motion planning of Multi-Rotor Aerial Vehicles (MRAVs)
using Free-Space Optical (FSO) links. The scenario involves MRAVs equipped with
body-fixed optical transmitters and Unmanned Ground Vehicles (UGVs) acting as
mobile relays, each outfitted with fixed conical Field-of-View (FoV) receivers.
The controller integrates optical connectivity constraints into the NMPC
formulation to ensure beam alignment and minimum link quality, while also
enabling UGV tracking and obstacle avoidance. The method supports both coplanar
and tilted MRAV configurations. MATLAB simulations demonstrate its feasibility
and effectiveness.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a Nonlinear Model Predictive Control framework for communication-aware motion planning of multi-rotor aerial vehicles, ensuring optical connectivity and enabling tracking and avoidance capabilities.
AI.motivation: The study aims to address the challenges of maintaining robust communication links in dynamic environments with aerial and ground vehicles using Free-Space Optical technology.
AI.method: The method involves integrating optical communication constraints into a NMPC formulation, enabling simultaneous beam alignment, link quality assurance, UGV tracking, and obstacle avoidance.
AI.result: MATLAB simulations were conducted, showing the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed control framework.
AI.conclusion: The framework successfully ensures optical link quality while navigating motion planning complexities for MRAVs and UGVs under different configurations.

title: LLMs model how humans induce logically structured rules
summary:
A central goal of cognitive science is to provide a computationally explicit
account of both the structure of the mind and its development: what are the
primitive representational building blocks of cognition, what are the rules via
which those primitives combine, and where do these primitives and rules come
from in the first place? A long-standing debate concerns the adequacy of
artificial neural networks as computational models that can answer these
questions, in particular in domains related to abstract cognitive function,
such as language and logic. This paper argues that recent advances in neural
networks -- specifically, the advent of large language models (LLMs) --
represent an important shift in this debate. We test a variety of LLMs on an
existing experimental paradigm used for studying the induction of rules
formulated over logical concepts. Across four experiments, we find converging
empirical evidence that LLMs provide at least as good a fit to human behavior
as models that implement a Bayesian probablistic language of thought (pLoT),
which have been the best computational models of human behavior on the same
task. Moreover, we show that the LLMs make qualitatively different predictions
about the nature of the rules that are inferred and deployed in order to
complete the task, indicating that the LLM is unlikely to be a mere
implementation of the pLoT solution. Based on these results, we argue that LLMs
may instantiate a novel theoretical account of the primitive representations
and computations necessary to explain human logical concepts, with which future
work in cognitive science should engage.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the utility of large language models (LLMs) in replicating human logical behavior and contrasts them against Bayesian probabilistic language of thought models.
AI.motivation: To address the ongoing debate about the adequacy of artificial neural networks, especially large language models, as computational models for abstract cognitive functions like language and logic.
AI.method: Four experiments tested LLMs on a paradigm for inducing rules over logical concepts, comparing their fit with human behavior against Bayesian probabilistic language of thought models.
AI.result: LLMs performed equally well, or better, compared to Bayesian probabilistic models while making distinct predictions about logical rules inferred, suggesting novel computational capabilities.
AI.conclusion: LLMs provide a new theoretical framework for cognitive science, challenging conventional models and promising insights into human logical cognition.

title: Optimisation Is Not What You Need
summary:
The Artificial Intelligence field has focused on developing optimisation
methods to solve multiple problems, specifically problems that we thought to be
only solvable through cognition. The obtained results have been outstanding,
being able to even surpass the Turing Test. However, we have found that these
optimisation methods share some fundamental flaws that impede them to become a
true artificial cognition. Specifically, the field have identified catastrophic
forgetting as a fundamental problem to develop such cognition. This paper
formally proves that this problem is inherent to optimisation methods, and as
such it will always limit approaches that try to solve the Artificial General
Intelligence problem as an optimisation problem. Additionally, it addresses the
problem of overfitting and discuss about other smaller problems that
optimisation methods pose. Finally, it empirically shows how world-modelling
methods avoid suffering from either problem. As a conclusion, the field of
Artificial Intelligence needs to look outside the machine learning field to
find methods capable of developing an artificial cognition.

AI.tldr: The paper identifies inherent flaws in optimization methods, like catastrophic forgetting, limiting their use for Artificial General Intelligence, advocating for alternative approaches beyond machine learning.
AI.motivation: To address the inherent limitations of optimization methods in achieving true artificial cognition, especially highlighting catastrophic forgetting as a barrier.
AI.method: The paper uses formal proof to establish that catastrophic forgetting is inherent to optimization methods and empirically demonstrates the efficacy of world-modeling approaches.
AI.result: It proves catastrophic forgetting is unavoidable with optimization techniques and showcases how world-modeling methods do not suffer from this issue.
AI.conclusion: Artificial Intelligence must explore methods outside traditional machine learning to achieve artificial cognition, as optimization approaches are fundamentally flawed.

title: GenAI-Powered Inference
summary:
We introduce GenAI-Powered Inference (GPI), a statistical framework for both
causal and predictive inference using unstructured data, including text and
images. GPI leverages open-source Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI)
models - such as large language models and diffusion models - not only to
generate unstructured data at scale but also to extract low-dimensional
representations that capture their underlying structure. Applying machine
learning to these representations, GPI enables estimation of causal and
predictive effects while quantifying associated estimation uncertainty. Unlike
existing approaches to representation learning, GPI does not require
fine-tuning of generative models, making it computationally efficient and
broadly accessible. We illustrate the versatility of the GPI framework through
three applications: (1) analyzing Chinese social media censorship, (2)
estimating predictive effects of candidates' facial appearance on electoral
outcomes, and (3) assessing the persuasiveness of political rhetoric. An
open-source software package is available for implementing GPI.

AI.tldr: Introduces GPI, a statistical framework leveraging Generative AI to conduct causal and predictive inference using unstructured data, with applications in social science.
AI.motivation: To enable efficient and accessible causal and predictive inference using unstructured data such as text and images, without requiring fine-tuning of generative models.
AI.method: Combines open-source generative AI models to extract low-dimensional representations of data for machine learning applications, avoiding fine-tuning.
AI.result: Demonstrated robustness in analyzing Chinese censorship, predicting electoral outcomes based on facial appearance, and assessing political rhetoric persuasiveness.
AI.conclusion: GPI offers a computationally efficient means to leverage unstructured data for causal and predictive inference, with broad applicability and open-source implementation available.

title: A Vision-Based Closed-Form Solution for Measuring the Rotation Rate of an Object by Tracking One Point
summary:
We demonstrate that, under orthographic projection and with a camera fixated
on a point located on a rigid body, the rotation of that body can be
analytically obtained by tracking only one other feature in the image. With
some exceptions, any tracked point, regardless of its location on the body,
yields the same value of the instantaneous rotation rate.
  The proposed method is independent of the shape of the 3D object and does not
require a priori knowledge about the scene. This algorithm is suited for
parallel processing and can achieve segmentation of the scene by distinguishing
points that do not belong to the same rigid body, simply because they do not
produce the same value of the rotation. This paper presents an analytical
derivation, simulation results, and results from real video data.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a method to determine rotation of a rigid body by analyzing a single feature in an image using orthographic projections.
AI.motivation: To provide a simpler approach for determining the rotation of a rigid body based on minimal visual input, eliminating the need for complex 3D object or scene knowledge.
AI.method: The method involves tracking a single feature in the image while a camera is fixated on a point on the rigid body. It utilizes orthographic projection and calculates the body's rotation analytically.
AI.result: The method successfully obtains the instantaneous rotation rate from a single tracked point, proving robust across simulations and real video data. Additionally, it segments scenes by identifying points that belong to different rigid bodies.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach works independently of the object's shape or scene knowledge, enabling efficient rotation calculation and scene segmentation from minimal input.

title: Identification of Potentially Misclassified Crash Narratives using Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL)
summary:
This research investigates the efficacy of machine learning (ML) and deep
learning (DL) methods in detecting misclassified intersection-related crashes
in police-reported narratives. Using 2019 crash data from the Iowa Department
of Transportation, we implemented and compared a comprehensive set of models,
including Support Vector Machine (SVM), XGBoost, BERT Sentence Embeddings, BERT
Word Embeddings, and Albert Model. Model performance was systematically
validated against expert reviews of potentially misclassified narratives,
providing a rigorous assessment of classification accuracy. Results
demonstrated that while traditional ML methods exhibited superior overall
performance compared to some DL approaches, the Albert Model achieved the
highest agreement with expert classifications (73% with Expert 1) and original
tabular data (58%). Statistical analysis revealed that the Albert Model
maintained performance levels similar to inter-expert consistency rates,
significantly outperforming other approaches, particularly on ambiguous
narratives. This work addresses a critical gap in transportation safety
research through multi-modal integration analysis, which achieved a 54.2%
reduction in error rates by combining narrative text with structured crash
data. We conclude that hybrid approaches combining automated classification
with targeted expert review offer a practical methodology for improving crash
data quality, with substantial implications for transportation safety
management and policy development.

AI.tldr: Investigated machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) for identifying misclassified intersection-related crash narratives, with results showing Albert Model as the most effective approach.
AI.motivation: To address gaps in the accuracy of police-reported crash narratives and improve the quality of crash data through automated methods.
AI.method: Implemented ML and DL models like SVM, XGBoost, and Albert on 2019 crash data; validated model outputs against expert reviews and tabular crash data.
AI.result: Albert Model showed the highest agreement with experts (73%) and tabular data (58%), reducing classification error rates by 54.2% when combining narrative text and structured data.
AI.conclusion: Hybrid methods integrating automated classification with expert review improve crash data accuracy and provide actionable insights for transportation safety management.

title: SimLauncher: Launching Sample-Efficient Real-world Robotic Reinforcement Learning via Simulation Pre-training
summary:
Autonomous learning of dexterous, long-horizon robotic skills has been a
longstanding pursuit of embodied AI. Recent advances in robotic reinforcement
learning (RL) have demonstrated remarkable performance and robustness in
real-world visuomotor control tasks. However, applying RL in the real world
faces challenges such as low sample efficiency, slow exploration, and
significant reliance on human intervention. In contrast, simulators offer a
safe and efficient environment for extensive exploration and data collection,
while the visual sim-to-real gap, often a limiting factor, can be mitigated
using real-to-sim techniques. Building on these, we propose SimLauncher, a
novel framework that combines the strengths of real-world RL and
real-to-sim-to-real approaches to overcome these challenges. Specifically, we
first pre-train a visuomotor policy in the digital twin simulation environment,
which then benefits real-world RL in two ways: (1) bootstrapping target values
using extensive simulated demonstrations and real-world demonstrations derived
from pre-trained policy rollouts, and (2) Incorporating action proposals from
the pre-trained policy for better exploration. We conduct comprehensive
experiments across multi-stage, contact-rich, and dexterous hand manipulation
tasks. Compared to prior real-world RL approaches, SimLauncher significantly
improves sample efficiency and achieves near-perfect success rates. We hope
this work serves as a proof of concept and inspires further research on
leveraging large-scale simulation pre-training to benefit real-world robotic
RL.

AI.tldr: SimLauncher is a novel framework combining simulation pre-training with real-world reinforcement learning to improve robotic skill acquisition.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of applying reinforcement learning (RL) in real-world scenarios, including low sample efficiency, slow exploration, and heavy dependence on human interventions.
AI.method: Propose SimLauncher, which pre-trains a visuomotor policy in simulation (digital twin) and uses the pre-trained model to guide real-world RL via target value bootstrapping and action proposal incorporation.
AI.result: SimLauncher significantly improves sample efficiency and achieves near-perfect success rates in multi-stage, dexterous robotic manipulation tasks when compared to prior real-world RL methods.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates the potential of large-scale simulation pre-training for enhancing real-world robotic RL and motivates future research in this direction.

title: Agent Exchange: Shaping the Future of AI Agent Economics
summary:
The rise of Large Language Models (LLMs) has transformed AI agents from
passive computational tools into autonomous economic actors. This shift marks
the emergence of the agent-centric economy, in which agents take on active
economic roles-exchanging value, making strategic decisions, and coordinating
actions with minimal human oversight. To realize this vision, we propose Agent
Exchange (AEX), a specialized auction platform designed to support the dynamics
of the AI agent marketplace. AEX offers an optimized infrastructure for agent
coordination and economic participation. Inspired by Real-Time Bidding (RTB)
systems in online advertising, AEX serves as the central auction engine,
facilitating interactions among four ecosystem components: the User-Side
Platform (USP), which translates human goals into agent-executable tasks; the
Agent-Side Platform (ASP), responsible for capability representation,
performance tracking, and optimization; Agent Hubs, which coordinate agent
teams and participate in AEX-hosted auctions; and the Data Management Platform
(DMP), ensuring secure knowledge sharing and fair value attribution. We outline
the design principles and system architecture of AEX, laying the groundwork for
agent-based economic infrastructure in future AI ecosystems.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Agent Exchange (AEX), an auction platform to facilitate the emerging agent-centric economy, where AI agents act as autonomous economic participants.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to enable autonomous AI agents to effectively participate in economic activities, create value, and coordinate with minimal human involvement.
AI.method: The authors propose an auction-based platform called Agent Exchange (AEX), inspired by Real-Time Bidding systems, and design a framework involving User-Side Platforms, Agent-Side Platforms, Agent Hubs, and Data Management Platforms.
AI.result: The paper defines the design principles and architecture of AEX, establishing a foundation for a marketplace accommodating AI agents' economic roles.
AI.conclusion: AEX provides infrastructure to support AI agents as independent economic players, advancing the development of agent-centric economies in future AI ecosystems.

title: Monitoring of Static Fairness
comment: arXiv admin note: text overlap with arXiv:2305.15979
summary:
Machine-learned systems are in widespread use for making decisions about
humans, and it is important that they are fair, i.e., not biased against
individuals based on sensitive attributes.
  We present a general framework of runtime verification of algorithmic
fairness for systems whose models are unknown, but are assumed to have a Markov
chain structure, with or without full observation of the state space.
  We introduce a specification language that can model many common algorithmic
fairness properties, such as demographic parity, equal opportunity, and social
burden.
  We build monitors that observe a long sequence of events as generated by a
given system, and output, after each observation, a quantitative estimate of
how fair or biased the system was on that run until that point in time.
  The estimate is proven to be correct modulo a variable error bound and a
given confidence level, where the error bound gets tighter as the observed
sequence gets longer.
  We present two categories of monitoring algorithms, namely ones with a
uniform error bound across all time points, and ones with weaker non-uniform,
pointwise error bounds at different time points.
  Our monitoring algorithms use statistical tools that are adapted to suit the
dynamic requirements of monitoring and the special needs of the fairness
specifications.
  Using a prototype implementation, we show how we can monitor if a bank is
fair in giving loans to applicants from different social backgrounds, and if a
college is fair in admitting students while maintaining a reasonable financial
burden on the society.
  In these experiments, our monitors took less than a millisecond to update
their verdicts after each observation.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a runtime verification framework to ensure algorithmic fairness in machine-learned systems, offering statistical monitors with quantitative bias/fairness estimates.
AI.motivation: Machine-learned systems influence decisions about humans, raising critical fairness concerns regarding sensitive attributes.
AI.method: The researchers developed monitors for Markov chain-based systems that provide real-time fairness assessments using statistical tools and a specification language for fairness properties.
AI.result: The approach yields quantitative fairness estimates with proven error bounds and high confidence, demonstrated in fairness monitoring for banks and colleges.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework efficiently monitors algorithmic fairness in real-time, making it applicable to real-world fairness-sensitive scenarios.

title: Risk-sensitive Actor-Critic with Static Spectral Risk Measures for Online and Offline Reinforcement Learning
summary:
The development of Distributional Reinforcement Learning (DRL) has introduced
a natural way to incorporate risk sensitivity into value-based and actor-critic
methods by employing risk measures other than expectation in the value
function. While this approach is widely adopted in many online and offline RL
algorithms due to its simplicity, the naive integration of risk measures often
results in suboptimal policies. This limitation can be particularly harmful in
scenarios where the need for effective risk-sensitive policies is critical and
worst-case outcomes carry severe consequences. To address this challenge, we
propose a novel framework for optimizing static Spectral Risk Measures (SRM), a
flexible family of risk measures that generalizes objectives such as CVaR and
Mean-CVaR, and enables the tailoring of risk preferences. Our method is
applicable to both online and offline RL algorithms. We establish theoretical
guarantees by proving convergence in the finite state-action setting. Moreover,
through extensive empirical evaluations, we demonstrate that our algorithms
consistently outperform existing risk-sensitive methods in both online and
offline environments across diverse domains.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a framework optimizing Spectral Risk Measures for risk-sensitive reinforcement learning, yielding superior performance over current methods.
AI.motivation: To enhance risk-sensitive reinforcement learning methods by addressing the limitations of suboptimal policies generated by naive risk measure integration.
AI.method: A novel static Spectral Risk Measure framework, applicable to online and offline RL algorithms, is presented, with theoretical convergence guarantees in finite settings.
AI.result: Demonstrated consistent outperformance of existing risk-sensitive RL approaches through empirical evaluations across various domains.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework effectively tailors risk preferences and improves RL algorithm performance in risk-critical scenarios.

title: Subject Invariant Contrastive Learning for Human Activity Recognition
summary:
The high cost of annotating data makes self-supervised approaches, such as
contrastive learning methods, appealing for Human Activity Recognition (HAR).
Effective contrastive learning relies on selecting informative positive and
negative samples. However, HAR sensor signals are subject to significant domain
shifts caused by subject variability. These domain shifts hinder model
generalization to unseen subjects by embedding subject-specific variations
rather than activity-specific features. As a result, human activity recognition
models trained with contrastive learning often struggle to generalize to new
subjects. We introduce Subject-Invariant Contrastive Learning (SICL), a simple
yet effective loss function to improve generalization in human activity
recognition. SICL re-weights negative pairs drawn from the same subject to
suppress subject-specific cues and emphasize activity-specific information. We
evaluate our loss function on three public benchmarks: UTD-MHAD, MMAct, and
DARai. We show that SICL improves performance by up to 11% over traditional
contrastive learning methods. Additionally, we demonstrate the adaptability of
our loss function across various settings, including multiple self-supervised
methods, multimodal scenarios, and supervised learning frameworks.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses generalization challenges in human activity recognition (HAR) using self-supervised contrastive learning by proposing a novel loss function called Subject-Invariant Contrastive Learning (SICL). SICL alleviates subject variability issues and improves generalization to new subjects.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to tackle the generalization problem in self-supervised human activity recognition (HAR) caused by domain shifts and subject variability in sensor signals.
AI.method: The proposed method, Subject-Invariant Contrastive Learning (SICL), introduces a loss function that re-weights negative pairs from the same subject to suppress subject-specific variations and highlight activity-specific features.
AI.result: Empirical results on three benchmarks (UTD-MHAD, MMAct, and DARai) demonstrate that SICL improves performance by up to 11% compared to traditional contrastive learning methods. It is also versatile across various frameworks and scenarios.
AI.conclusion: SICL effectively enhances generalization in HAR models, addressing subject-specific biases, and proves adaptable across self-supervised, multimodal, and supervised methods.

title: Large Language Models for Automating Clinical Data Standardization: HL7 FHIR Use Case
summary:
For years, semantic interoperability standards have sought to streamline the
exchange of clinical data, yet their deployment remains time-consuming,
resource-intensive, and technically challenging. To address this, we introduce
a semi-automated approach that leverages large language models specifically
GPT-4o and Llama 3.2 405b to convert structured clinical datasets into HL7 FHIR
format while assessing accuracy, reliability, and security. Applying our method
to the MIMIC-IV database, we combined embedding techniques, clustering
algorithms, and semantic retrieval to craft prompts that guide the models in
mapping each tabular field to its corresponding FHIR resource. In an initial
benchmark, resource identification achieved a perfect F1-score, with GPT-4o
outperforming Llama 3.2 thanks to the inclusion of FHIR resource schemas within
the prompt. Under real-world conditions, accuracy dipped slightly to 94 %, but
refinements to the prompting strategy restored robust mappings. Error analysis
revealed occasional hallucinations of non-existent attributes and mismatches in
granularity, which more detailed prompts can mitigate. Overall, our study
demonstrates the feasibility of context-aware, LLM-driven transformation of
clinical data into HL7 FHIR, laying the groundwork for semi-automated
interoperability workflows. Future work will focus on fine-tuning models with
specialized medical corpora, extending support to additional standards such as
HL7 CDA and OMOP, and developing an interactive interface to enable expert
validation and iterative refinement.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a semi-automated method using GPT-4o and Llama 3.2 405b to convert clinical datasets into the HL7 FHIR format with high accuracy, evaluated using the MIMIC-IV database.
AI.motivation: Semantic interoperability standards for clinical data remain challenging to implement due to their complexity and resource-intensive nature. The study aims to streamline this process using large language models.
AI.method: The method combines embedding techniques, clustering algorithms, and semantic retrieval to generate prompts guiding LLMs in mapping clinical data fields to FHIR resources. GPT-4o and Llama 3.2 were benchmarked under different conditions.
AI.result: The method achieved a perfect F1-score in resource identification and a 94% accuracy rate under real-world conditions. Errors such as hallucinations and mismatches were addressed by refining prompts.
AI.conclusion: The study confirms that LLMs like GPT-4o can effectively enable semi-automated, context-aware clinical data transformation into FHIR. Future work will focus on model fine-tuning, expanding support to other standards, and developing expert validation interfaces.

title: Verification of Visual Controllers via Compositional Geometric Transformations
summary:
Perception-based neural network controllers are increasingly used in
autonomous systems that rely on visual inputs to operate in the real world.
Ensuring the safety of such systems under uncertainty is challenging. Existing
verification techniques typically focus on Lp-bounded perturbations in the
pixel space, which fails to capture the low-dimensional structure of many
real-world effects. In this work, we introduce a novel verification framework
for perception-based controllers that can generate outer-approximations of
reachable sets through explicitly modeling uncertain observations with
geometric perturbations. Our approach constructs a boundable mapping from
states to images, enabling the use of state-based verification tools while
accounting for uncertainty in perception. We provide theoretical guarantees on
the soundness of our method and demonstrate its effectiveness across benchmark
control environments. This work provides a principled framework for certifying
the safety of perception-driven control systems under realistic visual
perturbations.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a framework for verifying the safety of perception-based controllers by explicitly modeling uncertain observations with geometric perturbations instead of conventional pixel-space techniques.
AI.motivation: Safety assurance of perception-based neural network controllers is challenging, especially under real-world visual uncertainties not well-represented by traditional pixel-based perturbation bounds.
AI.method: The authors design a verification framework using geometric perturbations and state-to-image mappings, integrating state-based verification tools to account for perception uncertainty.
AI.result: The framework demonstrated theoretical soundness and practical effectiveness across various control system benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: A principled framework for certifying safety in perception-driven control systems under realistic visual perturbations improves verification methodologies and addresses challenges of real-world uncertainties.

title: Animation Needs Attention: A Holistic Approach to Slides Animation Comprehension with Visual-Language Models
summary:
Slide animations, such as fade-ins, fly-ins, and wipes, are critical for
audience engagement, efficient information delivery, and vivid visual
expression. However, most AI-driven slide-generation tools still lack native
animation support, and existing vision-language models (VLMs) struggle with
animation tasks due to the absence of public datasets and limited
temporal-reasoning capabilities. To address this gap, we release the first
public dataset for slide-animation modeling: 12,000 triplets of
natural-language descriptions, animation JSON files, and rendered videos,
collectively covering every built-in PowerPoint effect. Using this resource, we
fine-tune Qwen-2.5-VL-7B with Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) and achieve consistent
improvements over GPT-4.1 and Gemini-2.5-Pro in BLEU-4, ROUGE-L, SPICE, and our
Coverage-Order-Detail Assessment (CODA) metric, which evaluates action
coverage, temporal order, and detail fidelity. On a manually curated test set
of slides, the LoRA model increases BLEU-4 by around 60%, ROUGE-L by 30%, and
shows significant improvements in CODA-detail. This demonstrates that low-rank
adaptation enables reliable temporal reasoning and generalization beyond
synthetic data. Overall, our dataset, LoRA-enhanced model, and CODA metric
provide a rigorous benchmark and foundation for future research on VLM-based
dynamic slide generation.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the first public dataset for slide-animation modeling, along with a fine-tuned vision-language model that outperforms existing benchmarks in animation-related tasks.
AI.motivation: AI-driven slide-generation tools lack native animation support, and current vision-language models struggle with animation tasks due to a lack of datasets and poor temporal-reasoning capabilities.
AI.method: The authors release a dataset of 12,000 labeled triplets (description, animation JSON, video) and fine-tune Qwen-2.5-VL-7B using Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA). They evaluate performance with standard metrics (BLEU-4, ROUGE-L, SPICE) and introduce a new metric: CODA.
AI.result: The LoRA-enhanced model outperforms existing benchmarks (GPT-4.1 and Gemini-2.5-Pro), with significant improvements in BLEU-4 (60% increase), ROUGE-L (30% increase), and CODA-detail scores.
AI.conclusion: The new dataset, LoRA-enhanced model, and CODA metric offer a solid foundation and benchmark for improving animation capabilities in vision-language models, demonstrating enhanced temporal reasoning and generalization.

title: From 2:4 to 8:16 sparsity patterns in LLMs for Outliers and Weights with Variance Correction
summary:
As large language models (LLMs) grow in size, efficient compression
techniques like quantization and sparsification are critical. While
quantization maintains performance with reduced precision, structured sparsity
methods, such as N:M sparsification, often fall short due to limited
flexibility, and sensitivity to outlier weights. We explore 8:16
semi-structured sparsity, demonstrating its ability to surpass the Performance
Threshold-where a compressed model matches the accuracy of its uncompressed or
smaller counterpart under equivalent memory constraints. Compared to 2:4
sparsity, 8:16 offers greater flexibility with minimal storage overhead (0.875
vs. 0.75 bits/element). We also apply sparse structured patterns for salient
weights, showing that structured sparsity for outliers is competitive with
unstructured approaches leading to equivalent or better results. Finally, we
demonstrate that simple techniques such as variance correction and SmoothQuant
like weight equalization improve sparse models performance.

AI.tldr: The paper explores 8:16 semi-structured sparsity for compressing large language models, achieving superior accuracy and efficiency over traditional sparsity methods.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the shortcomings of existing structured sparsity techniques, like N:M sparsity, which struggle with flexibility and sensitivity to outlier weights as LLMs grow in size.
AI.method: The paper introduces a more adaptable 8:16 semi-structured sparsity and investigates its storage overhead. Methods to address outlier issues, such as structured sparsity for salient weights and variance correction, are also employed to enhance model performance.
AI.result: 8:16 sparsity achieves flexibility with minimal storage overhead, surpassing existing 2:4 sparsity in efficiency. Structured sparsity methods for outliers perform competitively with unstructured ones.
AI.conclusion: The proposed sparsity technique and optimization methods enhance the compression and efficiency of large language models while maintaining or improving performance.

title: Return of the Latent Space COWBOYS: Re-thinking the use of VAEs for Bayesian Optimisation of Structured Spaces
comment:
Accepted for publication at the International Conference on Machine
  Learning (ICML) 2025
summary:
Bayesian optimisation in the latent space of a Variational AutoEncoder (VAE)
is a powerful framework for optimisation tasks over complex structured domains,
such as the space of scientifically interesting molecules. However, existing
approaches tightly couple the surrogate and generative models, which can lead
to suboptimal performance when the latent space is not tailored to specific
tasks, which in turn has led to the proposal of increasingly sophisticated
algorithms. In this work, we explore a new direction, instead proposing a
decoupled approach that trains a generative model and a Gaussian Process (GP)
surrogate separately, then combines them via a simple yet principled Bayesian
update rule. This separation allows each component to focus on its strengths --
structure generation from the VAE and predictive modelling by the GP. We show
that our decoupled approach improves our ability to identify high-potential
candidates in molecular optimisation problems under constrained evaluation
budgets.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a decoupled approach combining a Variational AutoEncoder (VAE) and Gaussian Process (GP) for optimizing complex domains like molecular design.
AI.motivation: Existing models coupling VAE and surrogate models lack flexibility, leading to suboptimal performance in tasks where latent space isn't tailored, necessitating more complex algorithms.
AI.method: A decoupled strategy is introduced where the VAE handles structure generation, and the GP, trained separately, performs predictive modeling. They are integrated via a Bayesian update rule.
AI.result: The approach enhances the identification of promising candidates in molecular optimization tasks within constrained evaluation budgets.
AI.conclusion: Separating VAE and GP improves performance by allowing each to specialize, offering an effective solution for structured domain optimization.

title: LACONIC: A 3D Layout Adapter for Controllable Image Creation
summary:
Existing generative approaches for guided image synthesis of multi-object
scenes typically rely on 2D controls in the image or text space. As a result,
these methods struggle to maintain and respect consistent three-dimensional
geometric structure, underlying the scene. In this paper, we propose a novel
conditioning approach, training method and adapter network that can be plugged
into pretrained text-to-image diffusion models. Our approach provides a way to
endow such models with 3D-awareness, while leveraging their rich prior
knowledge. Our method supports camera control, conditioning on explicit 3D
geometries and, for the first time, accounts for the entire context of a scene,
i.e., both on and off-screen items, to synthesize plausible and semantically
rich images. Despite its multi-modal nature, our model is lightweight, requires
a reasonable number of data for supervised learning and shows remarkable
generalization power. We also introduce methods for intuitive and consistent
image editing and restyling, e.g., by positioning, rotating or resizing
individual objects in a scene. Our method integrates well within various image
creation workflows and enables a richer set of applications compared to
previous approaches.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a method to make text-to-image diffusion models 3D-aware, enabling better image synthesis and editing for multi-object scenes.
AI.motivation: Existing methods for guided image synthesis struggle to maintain consistent 3D structures in multi-object scenes as they rely primarily on 2D controls.
AI.method: The authors propose a new conditioning approach, training method, and adapter network for text-to-image diffusion models. This enhances the models' 3D-awareness and incorporates the entire scene context.
AI.result: The proposed model supports camera control, conditioning on 3D geometries, and handles on- and off-screen context to create plausible and semantically rich images. It also generalizes well despite being lightweight and using limited supervised data.
AI.conclusion: This method outperforms previous approaches by integrating into various workflows and enabling robust, intuitive 3D-focused editing and creation tasks.

title: ARF-RLHF: Adaptive Reward-Following for RLHF through Emotion-Driven Self-Supervision and Trace-Biased Dynamic Optimization
summary:
With the rapid advancement of Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback
(RLHF) and autoregressive transformers, state-of-the-art models such as
GPT-4.0, DeepSeek R1, and Llama 3.3 increasingly emphasize answer depth and
personalization. However, most existing RLHF approaches (e.g., PPO, DPO) still
rely on a binary-preference (BT) paradigm, which, while reducing annotation
costs, still requires substantial human effort and captures only group-level
tendencies rather than individual preferences. To overcome these limitations,
we propose Adaptive Reward-Following (ARF), a self-assessment framework that
leverages a high-precision emotion analyzer achieving over 70% accuracy on
GoEmotions, Sentiment140, and DailyDialog to convert free-form user feedback
into continuous preference scores. We further enrich and debias these signals
through lightweight data augmentations, including synonym replacement, random
trace truncation, and score bias annotation algorithm. A Dynamic Adapter
Preference Tracker continuously models evolving user tastes in real time,
enabling our novel Trace Bias (TB) fine-tuning algorithm to optimize directly
on these tracked rewards instead of coarse binary labels. Experiments on
Qwen-2/2.5, Gemma-2, and Llama-3.2 across four preference domains demonstrate
that ARF achieves an improvement of 3.3% over PPO and 7.6% over DPO. Moreover,
TB preserves theoretical alignment with PPO and DPO objectives. Overall, ARF
presents a scalable, personalized, and cost-effective approach to RLHF LLMs
through autonomous reward modeling.

AI.tldr: Adaptive Reward-Following (ARF) introduces a novel framework to convert user feedback into continuous preference scores, surpassing traditional binary-preference paradigms in RLHF.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the limitations of binary-preference paradigms in Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF), which do not capture individual user preferences effectively.
AI.method: ARF uses a high-precision emotion analyzer for free-form feedback, enhancing it with data augmentations like synonym replacements and bias correction. Additionally, a Dynamic Adapter Preference Tracker evolves user taste modeling in real-time, enabling fine-tuning through Trace Bias fine-tuning algorithm.
AI.result: Experiments show ARF improves performance by 3.3% over PPO and 7.6% over DPO across preference domains, while maintaining theoretical alignment with traditional RLHF objectives.
AI.conclusion: ARF offers a scalable and personalized RLHF solution, enhancing individual preference modeling while reducing annotation costs.

title: VLM-TDP: VLM-guided Trajectory-conditioned Diffusion Policy for Robust Long-Horizon Manipulation
summary:
Diffusion policy has demonstrated promising performance in the field of
robotic manipulation. However, its effectiveness has been primarily limited in
short-horizon tasks, and its performance significantly degrades in the presence
of image noise. To address these limitations, we propose a VLM-guided
trajectory-conditioned diffusion policy (VLM-TDP) for robust and long-horizon
manipulation. Specifically, the proposed method leverages state-of-the-art
vision-language models (VLMs) to decompose long-horizon tasks into concise,
manageable sub-tasks, while also innovatively generating voxel-based
trajectories for each sub-task. The generated trajectories serve as a crucial
conditioning factor, effectively steering the diffusion policy and
substantially enhancing its performance. The proposed Trajectory-conditioned
Diffusion Policy (TDP) is trained on trajectories derived from demonstration
data and validated using the trajectories generated by the VLM. Simulation
experimental results indicate that our method significantly outperforms
classical diffusion policies, achieving an average 44% increase in success
rate, over 100% improvement in long-horizon tasks, and a 20% reduction in
performance degradation in challenging conditions, such as noisy images or
altered environments. These findings are further reinforced by our real-world
experiments, where the performance gap becomes even more pronounced in
long-horizon tasks. Videos are available on https://youtu.be/g0T6h32OSC8

AI.tldr: The paper introduces VLM-TDP, a VLM-guided trajectory-conditioned diffusion policy that significantly improves performance in robotic manipulation tasks, especially for long-horizon tasks and challenging environments.
AI.motivation: To enhance the performance of diffusion policies in robotic manipulation, which degrade in long-horizon tasks and under noisy image conditions.
AI.method: The approach utilizes state-of-the-art Vision-Language Models (VLMs) to break down long-horizon tasks into sub-tasks, create voxel-based trajectories, and condition diffusion policies for robust performance.
AI.result: The method achieves a 44% increase in success rate, over 100% improvement in long-horizon tasks, and a 20% reduction in degradation under challenging conditions in simulations, with reinforced better performance in real-world experiments.
AI.conclusion: VLM-TDP effectively addresses the limitations of traditional diffusion policies, making them viable for robust and complex robotic manipulation tasks including long-horizon scenarios.

title: CortexDebate: Debating Sparsely and Equally for Multi-Agent Debate
summary:
Nowadays, single Large Language Model (LLM) struggles with critical issues
such as hallucination and inadequate reasoning abilities. To mitigate these
issues, Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) has emerged as an effective strategy, where
LLM agents engage in in-depth debates with others on tasks. However, existing
MAD methods face two major issues: (a) too lengthy input contexts, which causes
LLM agents to get lost in plenty of input information and experiences
performance drop; and (b) the overconfidence dilemma, where self-assured LLM
agents dominate the debate, leading to low debating effectiveness. To address
these limitations, we propose a novel MAD method called "CortexDebate".
Inspired by the human brain's tendency to establish a sparse and dynamically
optimized network among cortical areas governed by white matter, CortexDebate
constructs a sparse debating graph among LLM agents, where each LLM agent only
debates with the ones that are helpful to it. To optimize the graph, we propose
a module named McKinsey-based Debate Matter (MDM), which acts as an artificial
analog to white matter. By integrating the McKinsey Trust Formula, a
well-established measure of trustworthiness from sociology, MDM enables
credible evaluations that guide graph optimization. The effectiveness of our
CortexDebate has been well demonstrated by extensive experimental results
across eight datasets from four task types.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces "CortexDebate," a novel Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) method designed to improve Large Language Models' (LLMs) reasoning by engaging selected agents in optimized sparse debates.
AI.motivation: Single Large Language Models (LLMs) suffer from issues like hallucinations and poor reasoning abilities. Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) methods aim to alleviate these problems but face challenges such as input complexity and overconfidence from dominating agents.
AI.method: The proposed "CortexDebate" constructs a sparse debate graph among LLM agents, allowing only helpful interactions. It incorporates the "McKinsey-based Debate Matter" (MDM) module, inspired by trust modeling in sociology, to dynamically optimize debate performance via credible evaluations.
AI.result: Experiments across eight datasets from four task types confirm CortexDebate's effectiveness in improving performance over traditional MAD methods.
AI.conclusion: CortexDebate alleviates key challenges in MAD methods, offering a more efficient and effective framework for enhancing LLMs' reasoning and overall task performance.

title: Automated Grading of Students' Handwritten Graphs: A Comparison of Meta-Learning and Vision-Large Language Models
summary:
With the rise of online learning, the demand for efficient and consistent
assessment in mathematics has significantly increased over the past decade.
Machine Learning (ML), particularly Natural Language Processing (NLP), has been
widely used for autograding student responses, particularly those involving
text and/or mathematical expressions. However, there has been limited research
on autograding responses involving students' handwritten graphs, despite their
prevalence in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM)
curricula. In this study, we implement multimodal meta-learning models for
autograding images containing students' handwritten graphs and text. We further
compare the performance of Vision Large Language Models (VLLMs) with these
specially trained metalearning models. Our results, evaluated on a real-world
dataset collected from our institution, show that the best-performing
meta-learning models outperform VLLMs in 2-way classification tasks. In
contrast, in more complex 3-way classification tasks, the best-performing VLLMs
slightly outperform the meta-learning models. While VLLMs show promising
results, their reliability and practical applicability remain uncertain and
require further investigation.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the use of multimodal meta-learning and vision large language models (VLLMs) for autograding handwritten graphs and text in STEM education, demonstrating their strengths in specific classification tasks.
AI.motivation: There is a growing need to efficiently and consistently assess students' mathematical understanding, especially in STEM curricula, where handwritten graphs are common but lack sufficient research in autograding methods.
AI.method: The study implements multimodal meta-learning models to grade images with handwritten graphs and compares their performance against Vision Large Language Models (VLLMs) on real-world datasets.
AI.result: Meta-learning models excel in 2-way classification tasks, while VLLMs perform slightly better in complex 3-way classification tasks. Both approaches show promise, though VLLMs' practical applicability remains uncertain.
AI.conclusion: Multimodal meta-learning models offer reliable performance for autograding simple tasks, while VLLMs require further investigation to determine their full potential in practical scenarios.

title: Real-TabPFN: Improving Tabular Foundation Models via Continued Pre-training With Real-World Data
summary:
Foundation models for tabular data, like TabPFN, achieve strong performance
on small datasets when pre-trained solely on synthetic data. We show that this
performance can be significantly boosted by a targeted continued pre-training
phase. Specifically, we demonstrate that leveraging a small, curated collection
of large, real-world datasets for continued pre-training yields superior
downstream predictive accuracy compared to using broader, potentially noisier
corpora like CommonCrawl or GitTables. Our resulting model, Real-TabPFN,
achieves substantial performance gains on 29 datasets from the OpenML AutoML
Benchmark.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Real-TabPFN, an enhanced foundation model for tabular data that outperforms its predecessor, TabPFN, through targeted continued pre-training on real-world datasets.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to improve the predictive accuracy of foundation models for tabular data by exploring the impact of using curated real-world datasets vs synthetic or broader noisier datasets.
AI.method: The method involves targeted continued pre-training using a small, selected set of large, real-world datasets, comparing results to other wider datasets like CommonCrawl and GitTables.
AI.result: Real-TabPFN demonstrates superior predictive accuracy and substantial performance gains across 29 datasets from the OpenML AutoML Benchmark compared to previous approaches.
AI.conclusion: Targeted continued pre-training on curated real-world datasets is significantly more effective for boosting the performance of tabular foundation models, presenting a preferable alternative to broader noisy datasets.

title: Investigating Redundancy in Multimodal Large Language Models with Multiple Vision Encoders
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) increasingly adopt multiple vision
encoders to capture diverse visual information, ranging from coarse semantics
to fine grained details. While this approach is intended to enhance visual
understanding capability, we observe that the performance gains from adding
encoders often diminish and can even lead to performance degradation, a
phenomenon we term encoder redundancy. This paper presents a systematic
investigation into this issue. Through comprehensive ablation studies on state
of the art multi encoder MLLMs, we empirically demonstrate that significant
redundancy exists. To quantify each encoder's unique contribution, we propose a
principled metric: the Conditional Utilization Rate (CUR). Building on CUR, we
introduce the Information Gap (IG) to capture the overall disparity in encoder
utility within a model.Our experiments reveal that certain vision encoders
contribute little, or even negatively, to overall performance, confirming
substantial redundancy. Our experiments reveal that certain vision encoders
contribute minimally, or even negatively, to the model's performance,
confirming the prevalence of redundancy. These findings highlight critical
inefficiencies in current multi encoder designs and establish that our proposed
metrics can serve as valuable diagnostic tools for developing more efficient
and effective multimodal architectures.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the issue of encoder redundancy in multimodal large language models using multiple vision encoders, showing that extra encoders can contribute minimally or negatively to performance.
AI.motivation: To identify and address inefficiencies in multimodal large language models using multiple vision encoders, as their contributions to performance can diminish or lead to degradation.
AI.method: Conducted ablation studies on state-of-the-art multi-encoder MLLMs and proposed two new metrics—Conditional Utilization Rate (CUR) and Information Gap (IG)—to measure encoder contributions and disparities.
AI.result: Empirical studies revealed significant redundancy, with some vision encoders adding little or harming model performance.
AI.conclusion: Current multi-encoder designs are inefficient, and the proposed metrics (CUR and IG) provide diagnostic tools to develop more effective and streamlined multimodal architectures.

title: RLVER: Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Emotion Rewards for Empathetic Agents
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) excel at logical and algorithmic reasoning, yet
their emotional intelligence (EQ) still lags far behind their cognitive
prowess. While reinforcement learning from verifiable rewards (RLVR) has
advanced in other domains, its application to dialogue-especially for emotional
intelligence-remains underexplored. In this work, we introduce RLVER, the first
end-to-end reinforcement learning framework that leverages verifiable emotion
rewards from simulated users to cultivate higher-order empathetic abilities in
LLMs. Within this framework, self-consistent affective simulated users engage
in dialogue rollouts and produce deterministic emotion scores during
conversations, serving as reward signals to guide the LLM's learning.
Fine-tuning publicly available Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct model with PPO boosts its
Sentient-Benchmark score from 13.3 to 79.2 while largely preserving
mathematical and coding competence. Extensive experiments reveal that: (i)
RLVER consistently improves multiple dialogue capabilities; (ii) Thinking and
non-thinking models show distinct trends--thinking models excel in empathy and
insight, while non-thinking models favor action; (iii) GRPO often yields stable
gains, while PPO can push certain capabilities to a higher ceiling; (iv) More
challenging environments are not always better-moderate ones can yield stronger
outcomes. Our results show that RLVER is a practical route toward emotionally
intelligent and broadly capable language agents.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces RLVER, a reinforcement learning framework advancing emotional intelligence in LLMs using simulated user feedback.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to address the gap in emotional intelligence capabilities in large language models (LLMs), which are otherwise proficient in logical and algorithmic reasoning.
AI.method: The RLVER framework uses verifiable emotion rewards from affective simulated users in dialogue rollouts, combined with fine-tuning via reinforcement learning using PPO on an LLM (Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct).
